Secondary  education  prepares  pupils  for  employment  at  entry  level

current  proportion  of  female  teachers  is  approximately  17%,  against 
the Government’s policy of having at least 30% female teachers.

3. 
The  Ministry  of  Education  (MOE)  is  responsible  for  policy  and  planning  for  secondary, 
vocational,  technical,  and  higher  education  in  Bangladesh.  The Directorate of Secondary and

inadequate to fulfill its responsibilities.  For quality assurance, DSHE has no effective inspection 
and  supervision  system  and  no  inspection  staff  at  Upazila  (subdistrict)  level.  Inspection  and 
supervision of teacher training institutions are unsatisfactory and irregular at best.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

While  Bangladesh  has  made  significant  progress  in  providing  access  to  secondary 
7. 
education to increasing numbers of students,  including girls, the quality of teaching, and hence 
student learning, continue to be a major concern. As a result,  dropout rates are high. Students 
who  manage  to  complete  secondary  education  are  unprepared  to  enter  the  workforce  or  to 
continue  with  their  education.  Assistance  focusing  particularly  on  improving  the  teacher 
education system and the quality of teaching is necessary. Subsector analysis is in Appendix 2. 
A  summary  is  provided  in  paras.  8–10.  Problem  and  constraints  analysis,  and  government 
actions to overcome them, are in Supplementary Appendix B.  
 

1. 

Quality 

8. 
The  main  constraint  to  provision  of  quality  secondary  education  in  Bangladesh  is  the 
acute shortage of trained secondary school teachers; fewer than half of the teachers have had 
any  teacher  training,  and  the  rest  are  poorly  trained.  The  teacher  recruitment  system  is 
inadequate,  lacks  transparency  and  has  many  unfair  practices.  Teaching  as  a  career  is  not 
valued and there are no incentives for rewarding teaching effort and excellence. Consequently, 
teacher  inertia  and  absenteeism  are  widespread.  The  problem  is  exacerbated  by  lack  of 
teaching  standards  on  which  to  build  a  quality  teacher  training  system.  The  curriculum and 
textbooks are outdated, and the prevailing learning culture and examination system emphasize 
learning  by  rote  rather  than  creative  thinking  and  practical  work  skills.  This situation, together 
with  a  shortage  of  teaching  and  learning  resources,  results  in  poor  teaching  quality  and 
classroom  performance.  Students  who  leave  the  system  are  generally  unprepared  to  face 
competition in a modern economy and in the global community. 
 

2. 

Systemic Problems 

9. 
The  absence  of  strategic  planning  and  coordination  for  teacher  training  in  secondary 
education  in  Bangladesh,  largely  owing  to  the  absence  of  a  functioning  authority  to  discharge 

  

 

3

this important responsibility, has contributed to the unsatisfactory situation. The uncoordinated 
operations of multiple  teacher  training  institutions,  with  a  variety  of  teacher  training  programs 
and undefined training standards and competencies for teachers, make it difficult to identify and 
measure the quality of teachers during their initial training. The secondary education system has 
weak  organizational  and  supervisory  competence  and  lacks  the  capacity  to  monitor  and 
evaluate  performance  at  all  important  levels,  i.e.,  administrative,  teaching,  and  student  levels. 
Difficulties in evaluating and upgrading teacher performance in schools as a basis for in-service 
and  further  training  arise  from  a  lack  of  competencies  on  which  to  base  assessment  and 
inspection  results.  Efforts  to  improve  teaching  quality  are  also  hindered  by  the  insufficient 
funding and budgets of the secondary education system. Unfilled vacancies at all levels of the 
secondary education system are a major problem. 
 

3. 

Access and Equity 

10. 
A  major  issue  particularly  affecting  rural  areas  and  children  in  other  disadvantaged 
populations  is  inequitable  access  and  opportunity.  Development  partners  have been  working 
with the Government on a number of projects to alleviate the problems of access, particularly for 
girls,  through  stipend  programs.  More  equitable  access  to  teacher  training  should  also  be 
supported  for  female  students  and  students  from  rural  areas  and  disadvantaged  groups, 
including  ethnic  minorities.  Gender  and  social  development  policies  need  strengthening  to 
tackle  the  inequitable  gender balance in hiring  and assigning  female  teachers.  Little  attention 
has  been  paid  to  strengthening  gender  and  social  development  dimensions  and  embedding 
them in teacher training programs and materials. 
 

4.

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT  

A. 

Objectives 

The goal of the Project is to  enhance the quality of secondary education in Bangladesh 
12. 
secondary schools by improving the quality of teaching.  The purpose is to provide quality initial 
and  in-service  teacher  training,  including  continuing  professional  development,  to  all  eligible 
teachers of grades 6–10 in Government and private secondary schools. 
  
B. 

Components and Outputs 

13. 
The  Project  has  four  components:  (i)  improving  teaching  quality  through organizational 
development  and  capacity  building,  (ii)  improving  teacher  training  facilities,  (iii)  strengthening   
in-service  and  preservice  teacher  training,  and  (iv)  increasing  equitable  access  and  improving 
community  involvement.  Implementation  will  encompass  development  activities  at  central 
Government level, at all teacher training colleges and institutes, and on pilot basis at community 
level.

Improving  Teaching  Quality  Through  Organizational  Development  and 
Capacity Building 

14. 
Establishing  an  Integrated  Secondary  Teacher  Training  System.  A  number  of 
organizations,  including  teacher  training  colleges  (TTCs),  Madrasah  Teacher  Training  Institute 
(MTTI),  HSTTIs,  SESDC,  as  well  as  National  Academy  of  Educational  Management  (NAEM), 
National  University  (NU),  and  BOU,  are  currently  involved  in  providing  different  aspects  of 
teacher  training  in  secondary  education.  However,  there  is  a  clear  lack  of  coordination  and 
institutional  linkage  between  them.  To  overcome  this,  the  education  reform  recommendations 
include transformation and restructuring NAEM to become the institutional home of excellence 
for  secondary  education  teacher  training.  NAEM  will  be  responsible  for  managing  and 
coordinating  secondary  education  teacher  training  nationwide.  In  addition,  a  Nongovernment 
Teachers  Registration  and  Certification  Agency  (NTRCA)  will  be  established.  NTRCA  will  be   
responsible  for  certifying,  registering,  and  deploying  all  qualified  teachers  and  head  teachers 
working in secondary education, and accrediting teacher training programs. Under the NAEM, a 
national integrated secondary teacher training system will be established to link all levels of the 
training  network  from  the  central  administration  to  the  schools,  to  coordinate  and  manage 
teacher qualification and training. It will be important to link the process also with monitoring and 
evaluation  data  and  analysis  provided  by  the  Bangladesh  Bureau  of  Educational  Information 
and Statistics (BANBEIS) and with functions of DSHE. The Project will assist with reorganizing 
the structure and functions of the various institutions involved in this proposed training network.

23. 
Teacher Training  Accreditation.  Accreditation  is  a  crucial  element  for  controlling  the 
quality of the system of teacher training. Building on the current work of SESIP, the Project will 
enhance the quality of teacher education by improving the accreditation criteria and processes, 
enforcing  standards,  and  improving  the  design  of  the  teacher  training  syllabus  to  ensure  a 
nationally  standardized  and  accredited  Bachelor  of  Education  (BEd)  in  modular  form,  as  the 
basic  requisite  qualification  for  teaching  in  a  secondary  school.  The  current  accreditation 
procedures  and  monitoring  will  be  reviewed  and  will  be  improved,  including  those  for  private 
TTCs.  
 
A  modular  1-year  BEd  syllabus,  currently  being  developed  with  support  from  SESIP,

In-Service Initial Teacher Training—Teacher Training Certificate .  A major initiative 
will  be  to  develop  and  implement  a  new  in-service  teacher  training  program  to  train  untrained 
teachers currently serving in schools.  Training will be carried out in a phased manner in a two-
stage  system.  A  basic  in-service  training  course  at  certificate  level  will  be  designed  and

provide exemption from the specified parts of the BEd contained in the module. The activities at 
the colleges and training institutions will be supported through provision of training coordinators

(i.e.,  enhancement  of  salary  subvention)  will  be  awarded  on  completion  of  the  training  and 
successful teachers will be registered as “qualified.”

Currently there are an estimated 150,000 untrained teachers in secondary schools and 
the  limited  time  and  resources  available  make  it  impossible  to  train  all  of  them  within  a

undergo  compulsory  certificate  training,  giving  an  estimated  overall  target  of  about  100,000

During  this  period,  or  soon  after,  many  of  the  older  untrained  teachers  will  retire,  and  with 
compulsory  training  on  entry  it  is  anticipated  that  the  entire  secondary  teacher  workforce  will 
gradually  move  toward  qualification  to  a  minimum  level  over  a  period  approximately  10  years, 
and eventually to an entirely BEd standard secondary teacher workforce.

A. 

Expected Benefits 

58. 
The  Project  focuses  on  systemic  improvement  in  delivery  of  teacher  training  in 
secondary  education,  and  its  planning,  management,  and  monitoring.  The  improvements will 
establish  the  necessary  foundation  for  more  efficient  and  effective  teacher  training  and 

  16

improvement  in  quality  of  teaching  and  learning  in  secondary  schools.  Key  improvements  that 
will contribute to the sustainable development of better quality secondary education include the 
development  of  high  quality  initial  and  in-service  training  programs  for  teachers  and  head 
teachers.  Quality  improvements  will  include  also  improved  training  materials  and  facilities.  
The  training  programs  will  ensure  greater  use  of  classroom  practices  that  are  appropriate  for 
teaching  and  learning  in  secondary  education.  In  support  of  project  implementation,  
the  Government  will  introduce  compulsory  teacher  qualification  requirements  in  secondary 
education. This is likely to create more demand for better organized teacher training, particularly 
among the vast numbers of untrained teachers in secondary education. As 30% of the teachers 
will reach retirement age at project completion or soon after, the efficiency and benefits of the 
investment  will  further  be  achieved  by  prioritizing  teachers  under  40  years  of  age  for  training 
under  the  Project.  Ensuring  that  these  improvements  reach  beyond  the  urban  areas  to  the 
furthest  regions  will  help  overcome  the  barriers  caused  by  remoteness  and  geography.  
Access of candidates from remote areas and disadvantaged groups to teacher training will be 
supported.  However,  none  of  these  improvements  will  be  sustainable  without  enhanced 
capacity and efficiency of the teacher training system. The long-term benefits will be improved 
organizational  and  institutional  development,  human  resource  development  strategies  for 
teacher  training,  and  the  provision  of  additional  financial  and  other  resources  that  will  ensure 
greater long-term sustainability of secondary teacher training, both technically and financially.

commitment.  This  risk  is  mitigated  by  the  fact  that  the  reforms  are  linked  with  wider  long-term 
development frameworks in the sector and beyond, with the national poverty reduction strategy, 
and the medium-term macroeconomic framework (MTMF).

63. 
There is also a risk that the Government may not be able to allocate adequate financial 
counterpart  resources  for  the  Project.  Therefore,  as  part  of  the  risk  mitigation  analysis  and 
preparation of the financial plan,  financial affordability and sustainability of the proposed  Project 
was  analyzed  based  on  the  MTMF  in  National  Strategy  for  Economic  Growth,  Poverty 
Reduction  and  Social  Development,  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  Staff  Report,  and 
Bangladesh  Public  Expenditure  Review. As  a  result  of  the  administrative  changes,  upgraded 
training facilities, and training grants introduced by the proposed  Project, there is a direct cost 
implication in the recurrent budget for teacher training after the project period. Approximately an 
additional Tk17 million will be required. In addition, it is estimated that another Tk28 million will 
be necessary every 5 years after the project period to cover the cost of major maintenance of 
buildings and furniture. These amounts can be sufficiently financed  through the proposed 10% 
annual  increase  in real terms  in  the  teacher  training  budget.  A corresponding assurance has 
been  included  in  the  loan  agreement.  Given  the  relatively  small  size  of  the  teacher  training 
budget,  the  required  increase  would  be  only  about  Tk30  million  by  the  end  of  the  Project.   
Such an increase can be absorbed by the increase in the overall secondary education budget. 
In  terms  of  indirect  cost  implications,  changes  in  the  teacher  qualification  policy  during  the 
project period  will  lead  to  salary  increase  from  untrained  to  trained  teacher  pay  scale levels. 
There  will  be  approximately  133,000    more  trained  teachers  by  2011  (including training both 
serving  untrained  teachers  and  new  teachers).  It  is  estimated  that  the  increase in  number of 
trained teachers will require  approximately an additional Tk503 million to Tk1,436 million by the 
end of the Project, depending  on how many teachers who receive initial training will  continue to 
BEd  level  training.  In addition,  depending  on  the  salary  level  of  teachers  working  in  remote 
areas, indirect costs in the range of Tk285 million–Tk327 million will be incurred in providing the 
proposed incentives for secondary school teachers in remote areas. The total additional budget 
requirement  as  a  result  of  indirect  costs  will  be  in  range  of  Tk788  million–Tk1,763  million.  
Such  increase  can  be  absorbed  by  increments  in  the  secondary  education  budget  between 
2005 and 2011 under the base case scenario, based on ADB and IMF analysis of the economy. 
The summary of the economic and financial analyses is in Supplementary Appendix I.  
 
64. 
There is a risk that no sufficient demand for teacher training may materialize. By project 
effectiveness,  the  Government  will  have  approved  a  policy  requiring  that  all  new  secondary 
teachers  must  be  trained  to  a  minimum  1  year  BEd  level  and  no  untrained  teachers  will  be 
appointed  to  teacher  posts  in  secondary  schools  after  2007.  The  policy  will  increase  the 
demand  and  motivation  of  untrained  teachers  for  training.  However,  the  opportunity  costs  of 
female  teachers  and  teachers  from  remote  areas  or  other  disadvantaged  groups  may  be  too 
high. This risk is mitigated by providing training grants for participants from these groups, and a 
salary incentive for teachers in remote areas. The strategy tested by  PROMOTE, which will be 
continued  by  the  proposed  Project,  is  important  for motivating SMCs to send female teachers 
for  training,  since  the  strategy  supports  not  only  female  teachers’  participation,  but  also  the 
provision of a substitute teacher for the school while the female teacher is in training.

transparent procedures in this area are expected to significantly mitigate the risk of abuse and

Contribution of the sector/sub-sector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh: 
 
In the Government’s poverty reduction statement, deprivation in health, education, and nutrition are used as indicators 
of human poverty. Bangladesh has shown strong national commitment to education. In recent years, Bangladesh has 
made major strides in the education sector.  The increased allocation to education in the development budget during 
the last 2 years reflects the commitment of the Government and donor community to the field of education. Over the 
last  decade,  the  total  recurrent  expenditure  for  the  secondary  education  subsector  as  a  percentage  of  total 
government recurrent expenditure on education has increased. The allocation for the secondary and higher secondary 
education subsector for 2002–2003 represents about 41.6% of the total education budget.  The Ministry of Education’s 
Perspective  Plan  for  1995–2010  identifies  the  general  objectives  for  the  postprimary  subsector.  They  include  (i) 
attaining  universal  secondary  education  with  emphasis  on  work-oriented  education,  (ii)  improving  education  at  all 
levels,  (iii)  accelerated  expansion  of  female  education  at  all  levels,  (iv)  making  technical  education  and  vocational 
training more job oriented, and (v) reducing the rural-urban gaps in education facilities.   
 
Gross  enrollment  rates  at  the  secondary  level  have  significantly  increased,  and  the  introduction  of  the  female 
secondary  stipend  program  has  virtually  eliminated  gender  disparity,  at  least  up  to  the  secondary  school  certificate 
(SSC) course level. Currently Bangladesh has approximately 18,677 secondary schools with 9.4 million students. Out 
of the total, 4.6 million are boys and 4.7 million are girls. The gross enrollment rate in secondary education averages 
about  30%,  marked  by  significant  losses  as  grades  advance,  i.e.,  38%  in  junior secondary, 25% in secondary, and 
19% in higher secondary education. Teachers in the secondary schools number about 240,000.    
 
Despite  significant  progress  in  providing  more  students  with  access  to  secondary  education,  a  weakness  in  the 
secondary system  is  reflected  in  the  declining  quality  of  graduates  and  teachers.  Secondary  education  is  generally 
intended  for  the  11–17  years  old.  According  to  the  Bangladesh  Bureau  of  Educational  Information  and  Statistics 
(BANBEIS),  dropout  rates  average  44%  for  grades  6–10  (49%  for  girls)  and  38%  for  grades  11–12 (36% for girls). 
Pass  rates  for  the  SSC  and  higher  secondary  certificate  (HSC)  have  been  declining  since  1999.  In  2001,  students 
passing the grade 10 SSC and grade 12 HSC examinations were 35.22% and 28.41%, respectively.  The decline in 
the quality of education can be partly attributed to poor teaching. In the past, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has 
assisted  the  Government  in  establishing  a  basis  for  teacher  education  through  several  projects  including  the 
establishment of teacher training colleges (TTCs), secondary education science development centers (SESDCs), and 
higher  secondary  teacher  training  institutes  (HSTTIs).  However,  60%  of  the  teachers  are  still  untrained  and  most 
schools  lack  standard  conditions essential for the normal instructional process. About 98% secondary schools are 
private  schools.  Most  of  the  private  schools  do  not  follow  government  procedures  in  recruiting  teachers  and 
maintaining  quality  standards  for  teaching.  Many  secondary  schools  are  in  deplorable  physical  condition  with 
inadequate facilities. The problems in secondary education are multifaceted and include inadequate teacher training, 
weak  training  methodology  and  inadequate  curriculum,  poor  performance  of  teachers,  high  percentage of untrained 
teachers, lack of proper inspection and monitoring of teachers performance, poor teaching and learning environment, 
and overcrowded classrooms. The school curriculum, the examination system, and quality of textbooks are all related 
issues that are being addressed in depth by the on-going ADB-supported Secondary Education Sector Improvement 
Project (SESIP).   
 
The goal of the Teaching Quality Improvement in Secondary Education Project is to enhance the quality of education 
in Bangladesh secondary schools by improving the quality of teaching. The purpose is to provide quality initial and in-
service  teacher  training,  including  continuing  professional  development,  to  all  eligible  teachers  of  grades  6-10 in 
government and private secondary schools. The Project will emphasize the quality of teaching methodology as well as 
the  learning  environment,  which  influences  quality,  standard  of  teaching,  and  school  performance.  The  Project  will 
address access to quality teaching by the poor, the disadvantaged, ethnic minorities, and refugee children.  
 
The Project will also provide training to untrained teachers in madrasah secondary schools, and this training will have 
a significant effect on the madrasah school system. Better trained teachers and students from madrasah schools will 
have a positive impact on social dynamics in the communities.

B.     Poverty Analysis                                                                 Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention1 

 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Bangladesh,  with  a  population  of  132  million  and  per  capita  gross  national  product  of  $350,  is  one  of  the  poorest 
countries  in  the  world.  However,  estimates  based  on  a  household  expenditure  survey  indicate  that  the  incidence  of 
income  poverty  has  declined  from  over  70%  of  the  population  in  1973  to  an  estimated  36%  in  2001. Progress has 
been made in improving Bangladesh’s human poverty index. Between 1992 and 1998, the index increased by 49%, 
with marked improvements in life expectancy, adult literacy, gross primary school enrollment ratio; and decreases in 
infant mortality  rates,  total  fertility  rates,  and  dropout  rates  in  primary  schools.  These  results  were  achieved  through 
continued efforts of the Government and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) to expand the coverage of essential 
services to the disadvantaged sections of society. Yet, Bangladesh faces severe deficiencies in the quality of health, 
nutrition, and education. The majority of the poor (about 80%) live in rural areas and most are illiterate. Most of the 
benefits  of  secondary  education  are  enjoyed  by  comparatively  better-off  families.  The  vast  majority  of  the  students 
who leave and remain outside the secondary education system belong to various disadvantaged groups, including the 
poor,  and  landless  or  marginal  farmers  in  rural  areas,  urban  slum  dwellers,  children of ethnic minorities, refugees, 
disabled children, and girls.   
 
The Government has attempted to ensure adequate access to basic social services, including secondary education, 
as  one  of  the  key  strategies  for  reducing  poverty.  The  Project  will  improve  secondary  school  teaching  quality  and 
create a teaching environment that is conducive to learning and the retention of students within the school system. 
The knowledge and skills the students will acquire will translate into social and economic benefits .  
 
The  project  component  equitable  access  and  community  involvement—will include interventions to increase access 
for  underserved  areas  and  disadvantaged  groups.  In  both  initial  and  in-service  training  to  teachers,  priority  will  be 
given to improving teaching quality in the remote and underserved areas. Three outreach stations or satellite teacher 
resource  centers  will  be  established  to  improve  access  to  teacher  education  in  remote  districts  such  as  Rangamati, 
Patuakhali, and Thakurgaon. To encourage teachers in remote areas, a teacher deployment policy will be developed. 
Special  teaching  and  learning  materials  will  be  prepared  for  teachers  working  with  children  from  various 
disadvantaged groups such as the disabled, ethnic tribes, and refugees. An awareness program will be developed for 
the school management committee (SMC), parent and support groups, and NGOs to promote better understanding 
and support for teachers working with the poor and disadvantaged groups. 
 
Project activities such as distance education, the school cluster system, and new in-service teacher training programs, 
enhanced  preservice  training,  and  improved  incentives  to  teachers,  especially  the  allowance  for  rural  teachers,  are 
expected to primarily benefit underserved and poor areas by providing better quality of teaching in secondary schools. 
With  improved  teaching  quality,  secondary  school  students  from  poor  families  will  have  a  better  chance  to  acquire 
knowledge and skills for direct entry into the labor market or for pursuing further education. The consequences of this 
improvement  will  have  an  impact  on  poverty  reduction  in  the  country,  as  experience  has  shown  that  improving  the 
human capital of the poor is highly successful in fighting poverty.

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Girls'  enrollment  at  the  secondary  level  has  significantly  improved.  Gross  enrollment  rates  for  girls  are  higher than 
those  for  boys  up  to  grade  10.  Much  of  the  improvement  can be attributed to the stipend programs, which support 
females with monthly stipends for educational expenses. But despite the positive trend in female secondary education, 
girls' performance at the SSC examination is inferior to that of boys. In 2002, the total pass rate was 41%, and it was 
38%  for  girls .  The  performance  of  girls  in  school  and  retention  rate  are  influenced  by  several  factors:  (i)  distance  of 
school and related safety and security; (ii) lack of female teachers in school; (iii) extra share of household duties for 
girls than for boys and less time for girls to prepare for examinations; and (iv) male teachers' lack of understanding of 
adolescent girls, early marriage of girls, etc.     
 
Government has a 30% quota for female teachers in secondary schools. A survey (1997), carried out by Program to 
Motivate,  Train  and  Employ  Female  Teachers  in  Rural  Secondary  Schools  (PROMOTE)  and  financed  by  the 
European Commission, showed that women compromise only 5% of the teachers on the monthly payroll in secondary 
schools  in  rural  areas  and  20–30%  in  urban  areas.  In  the  remote  rural  areas,  50%  of  the  schools  have  never 
employed a woman teacher. PROMOTE identified several factors preventing women from taking up employment as 
teachers: (i) social hindrance; (ii) tradition of male employment; (iii) lack of safe and decent accommodation; and       
(iv) lack of school facilities suitable for women, e.g. lack of separate toilet facilities, and lack of separate sitting area.  

The  recruitment  practices  of  SMCs  also  hinder  women’s  employment  in  teaching.  The  SMC  requires  the  potential 
teacher to make a donation to the school. Parents prefer to make donation for the employment of a son but not for a 
daughter.  PROMOTE  addresses  these  issues  through  activities  that  include  campaign  and  advocacy,  provision  of 
fellowship for female teachers to participate in teacher training, and refurbishment of schools and hostels for women 
teachers.  The present membership structure of SMCs in secondary schools does not include female members. The
